snippet: An analysis by two law professors concludes that Secure Communities, a federal program intended to improve public safety, has had “no observable effect” on crime rates.
abstract: Study to be published in Journal of Law and Economics concludes that six-year-old federal immigration enforcement program that has deported hundreds of thousands of people has had no observable effect on the overall crime rate; findings call into question the longstanding assumption that deporting noncitizens who commit crimes is an effective crime-control strategy.
lead_paragraph: An analysis by two law professors concludes that Secure Communities, a federal program intended to improve public safety, has had “no observable effect” on crime rates.

headline.main: Deportations Have ‘No Observable Effect’ on Crime Rate, Study Concludes
headline.print_headline: Deportations Have ‘No Observable Effect’ on Crime Rate, Study Concludes

keywords.value: Journal of Law and Economics, The
keywords.name: organizations
